headline: Lights Going Out at Famed N.Y. Eatery
summary: New York City's Tavern on the Green restaurant will close after New Year's Eve. The eatery, known for its Central Park address, is a victim of the recession and competition.

headline: Harper Suspends Canada's Parliament
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper is suspending Parliament until March to give his government time to "recalibrate."

headline: Noonan: Look Ahead With Stoicism—and Optimism
summary: While so many of our institutions have failed, we can repair them. The first step is to take personal responsibility.

headline: Disney Completes Marvel Deal
summary: Shareholders of Marvel Entertainment, home of Spider-Man and the Hulk, have approved the company's $4.3 billion acquisition by Disney, as expected.

headline: Europe Stocks End Year Up
summary: European shares closed slightly higher in a shortened final trading session of 2009 as the region wrapped up its best trading year in a decade.

headline: Treasury Ends TARP Bank Outlays
summary: The Treasury this week provided a combined $29.26 million in capital to 10 small banks across the U.S., the last outlays in a recapitalization effort.

headline: Oil Prices Settle at 7-Week High
summary: Crude-oil futures ended 2009 on an upbeat note, closing at a seven-week high, as cold weather boosted heating-oil demand and U.S. oil stocks declined.

headline: Gold Jumps 24% for the Year
summary: Gold futures held onto gains even as the dollar recovered from most of its early weakness. Spot-month gold was up 24% for the year.

headline: UTStarcom to Pay Fine for China Bribery

headline: Washington Times Drops Sports, Top Editor

summary: Read an excerpt from "Drive," by Daniel H. Pink.

headline: John Lewis Won't Raise Tax
summary: John Lewis joined the increasing number of U.K. retailers that won't be imposing the increased 17.5% value-added sales tax immediately.

headline: Treasury Prices Skid on Jobless Claims

summary: The U.N. is temporarily pulling about one-third of its international staff from Pakistan because of the deteriorating security situation.

headline: BSE Sensex Gains 81% in 2009

headline: Overstock.com, Liz Claiborne Lead Small-Caps

headline: Science Journals Must Be Unpolluted by Politics
summary: In his Dec. 18 op-ed "How to Manufacture a Climate Consensus," Patrick J. Michaels of the Cato Institute falsely claims that work by him (and other fossil-fuel-funded climate change contrarians) has been unfairly blocked by me and others from appearing in mainstream science journals because the peer review process is supposedly biased against climate science deniers. In truth, the only bias that exists at such publication is for well-reasoned writing that is buttressed by facts.

headline: Treasury Debt Sales Top $2.1 Trillion
summary: Wednesday's successful $32 billion seven-year note auction wraps up a record year of debt sales by the U.S. government.

headline: Perhaps We Can Alter the Climate
summary: There exists a field of study for geoengineering where concepts of how to alter the climate are studied. Such activities would change the old cliché that the weather is something everyone complains about but no one does anything about. Experience tells us that anything that can be shown to be scientifically possible can eventually be done. The history of volcanic eruptions resulting in significant world-wide, short-term temperature reductions provides examples of how materials injected into the upper atmosphere can affect such changes.

headline: Lending Highlights Europe Weakness
summary: Bank lending to companies operating in the euro zone fell in November, an indication that the recovery in the 16-nation currency bloc remains fragile.

summary: Four months into a crusade against Internet pornography, China is closing thousands of sites and tightening rules on who can register Web addresses inside China – yet the censors are losing.

headline: Alcoa Gains 1.7%, Helping Dow Tick Up

headline: High Hopes Come Crashing Down
summary: Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili's self-serving paean to his own failed presidency in his Dec. 19 op-ed "Georgia and the War in Afghanistan" is an object lesson in public relations over reality. Elected following his country's Rose Revolution, Mr. Saakashvili initially inspired high hopes that he would practice what he preached and bring democratic institutions to Georgia. Tens of millions of dollars were sent by Western countries to aid in this effort. Not surprisingly, Mr. Saakashvili's public-relations machine plays to the Western press, which, unlike that in his own country, is open and free.

headline: Fox, Time Warner Cable in Stand-Off
summary: Fox and Time Warner Cable are digging in their heels in negotiations over carriage fees, with News Corp. warning that an agreement is unlikely in time to prevent programming disruptions at midnight Thursday.

headline: Economy's Rescue Only Half Done
summary: Extraordinary government action prevented a depression. Hooray! But it's only halftime in Project Economic Rescue.

headline: 5.6 Million Reasons to Doubt Jobless Rate
summary: The way jobless claims have been receding should signal that U.S. unemployment has finally peaked. That probably isn't the case this time.

summary: Accused airline bomber Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab's affiliation with University College London is reviving concerns in Britain that its universities can breed Islamic radicalism.

summary: Russian consumer prices were flat for the week to Dec. 28, bringing Russia closer to achieving one of its lowest annual inflation readings this decade.

headline: 2009: Banner Year for Stocks
summary: U.S. stocks are poised to end a banner year, with the Dow industrials up 61% from their March nadir and 20% higher for 2009. Yet many investors remain wary.

summary: France's constitutional court struck down a new tax on carbon emissions, dealing a blow to President Sarkozy, who has made fighting climate change a key part of his tenure.

headline: Guilty Plea in Case With Alleged Iran Ties

headline: Packaged Travel Predicted to Grow
summary: Vacations may beat out staycations next year; Orbitzis offering up to 50% off at hotels world-wide; Marriott is boosting its rewards program this spring, more.

headline: A Partisan Assault On Child Safety Law
summary: Anne Northup notes that the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act (CPSIA) passed with bipartisan support, so it is surprising to see her partisan attack on this children's health protection law ("There Is No Joy in Toyland," op-ed, Dec. 24). She states that lead in metals used in children's products is not "bioavailable," and thus cannot harm children. This will come as a shock to Juanna Graham, whose son died after swallowing a metal charm. At least eight other children have suffered lead poisoning after sucking on and/or swallowing small lead pieces from toys or jewelry.

headline: Restaurants Put a Cork in Wine Fees
summary: The recession has pushed some Bay Area restaurateurs to waive their "corkage" fee as a way to attract customers.

headline: Estate-Tax Repeal Creates Dilemmas
summary: Spouses of those wealthy who die next year might find themselves with nothing if the wills aren't revised -- another wrinkle of the federal estate tax repeal.

headline: Here's a Resolution: Cut Spending
summary: Stepping into 2010, the prime ministers of the U.K., Spain, Greece and many other nations need to make cutting spending their priority for the new year, Patience Wheatcroft writes.

headline: Ex-Caijing Editor Launches Magazine
summary: Hu Shuli, one of China's best-known editors, has launched a new magazine after disputes over money and editorial policy caused her and most of her staff to leave Caijing.

headline: Yields Fall on Japanese Debt
summary: Japanese government bonds finished higher on the last trading day of the year as the market responded to overnight strength in U.S. Treasury debt and weakness in Tokyo stocks prompted demand for risk-free assets.

headline: Best Stock Fund of the Decade: CGM Focus
summary: Meet the decade's best-performing U.S. diversified stock mutual fund: Ken Heebner's $3.7 billion CGM Focus Fund, which rose more than 18% annually and outpaced its closest rival by more than three percentage points.

summary: Obama blamed the Northwest bombing attempt on security lapses, as it emerged that the U.S. had multiple pieces of information about the suspect.

headline: Traders Home In on OSI Systems and L-1
summary: Options traders looked at security companies after last week's failed bomb plot prompted governments to consider new screening technology.

headline: The Case Against the New Year
summary: Midnight revelry amounts to sheer malarkey, when the tradition that preceded it called for a reflective morning celebration. Simon Winchester blames the invention of public clocks.

headline: Turkmenistan Awards Gas Deal
summary: Turkmenistan awarded natural-gas contracts valued at $9.7 billion to several foreign energy companies, marking the latest step in the Central Asian nation's quest to become a major gas exporter.

headline: He Simply Strolled Through a Security System Hole
summary: When your Dec. 28 editorial "The Terror This Time" went to print, Secretary of Homeland Security Janet Napolitano had indeed stated that the aviation security "system worked" in foiling an attempted airplane bombing. Shortly thereafter, however, Ms. Napolitano claimed that her comment was taken out of context and that the system had not worked. Presumably her out-of-context original statement referred to the fact that the targeted airliner had landed safely thanks to passengers leaping out of their seats to subdue a man who had set his pants on fire while attempting to ignite an explosive. We'll see if the media give her a pass on her initial reaction; recall how the media treated ex-President Bush for his, "Brownie, you're doing a heck of a job" misguided statement to FEMA official Michael Brown in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Dec. 31, 2009.

summary: Mortgage lenders and brokers will be required to give consumers better estimates of the costs they incur when taking out loans.

headline: U.K. Bank Group Assails Reform
summary: The U.K.'s leading banking association ended 2009 with a bang, accusing authorities of impulsive reforms that could undermine the U.K. as a top financial center and crimp future economic growth.

headline: South Korea Drops Chip Probe
summary: Antitrust officials said they didn't find evidence of price fixing by manufacturers of flash-memory chips in South Korea or elsewhere and is ending its nearly three-year investigation.

summary: Returning Gitmo's detainees to Yemen defies common sense.

headline: Chicken Wire Spurs Wi-Fi Failures

headline: U.K. Property Fund Winds Down
